Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Detailed Characterization of Graphene Quantum Dots of Controlled Size, Shape and Chemistry

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provides funding to conduct a detailed study on a novel nanotomy (nanoscale cutting) process to produce graphene quantum dots (GQDs) of well-defined size (10-100 nm), shape (square, rectangle, and triangle), and chemistry (pristine and functionalized); and to thoroughly characterize their structural, optical and electrical properties and property-correlations. By controllably scaling down graphene into nanosized GQDs, its properties can be tuned over a wide spectrum, thus significantly broadening the scope of its applications. In this project, nanotomy of graphite and its subsequent exfoliation will be employed to produce large-quantities of monodisperse GQDs with controlled structure and chemistry. This will be followed by: (a) thorough characterization of the nanotomy-process to determine the GQD size distribution, shape consistency, functionalization density, edge smoothness, defect types and density, crystallography, and nanotomy characteristics; (b) detailed optical and electrical characterization (band-gap; net carrier mobility and density, and carrier transport mechanism in GQD films); and (c) establishing the correlations and theoretical models defining the GQD properties. The results from the correlations and models will be analyzed to further engineer the nanotomy process to fine-tune GQDs' properties.

Development of production-routes and fundamental property-correlations of important nanomaterials have revolutionized nanotechnology. However, synthesis and experimental characterization of GQDs have been a challenge. If successful, the results of this research will develop a novel route to produce well-defined GQDs and uncover their fundamental properties. The models and correlations established will enable direct tuning of GQD properties and rational design of its applications for the semiconductor industry. GQDs could potentially have the same impact that other carbon-nanomaterials have had. Further, the research activities will be integrated with various educational efforts. Nanoprocessing concepts will be incorporated into engineering education at Kansas State University to strengthen its nanotechnology base; new nanoprocessing and nanotechnology activities will be added to university outreach programs designed to improve participation of women/underrepresented students in engineering; and the students will be exposed to diverse research cultures to broaden their perspective on the scope of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A novel nanotomy (nanoscale cutting) process was established to produce graphene quantum dots (GQDs) of controlled size, shape (square, rectangle, and triangle), and chemistry (pristine and functionalized).

Intellectual Merits: (a) The mechanism of nanoscale cutting of graphite into nano-blocks of graphite was established with nanoscale cutting producing smoother zigzag edges than armchair edges in GQDs. (b) The evolution of a band-gap in graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) with reduction in their width was established via low-temperature electrical conductivity measurements. (c) The smoothness of GNR’s edges was studied by Raman analysis of the ratio of the intensities of the D-band and the G-band. (d) Several functionalization schemes were developed to functionalize the edges of the GQDs with different molecular groups. (e) GQDs were incorporated into hygroscopic polymer fibers to build a humidity sensor and the mechanism of operation was established. (f) Poly-L-Lysine functionalized GQDs were interfaced with the cell-wall of bacterial-spores to fabricate a bio-electronic device for fast humidity sensing. (g) New processes were developed to synthesize GQDs without nanotomy of graphite. These processes were applied on molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) to produce MoS2 quantum dots. (h) Electron transport mechanism in a network of GQDs and GQDs/BN was established. The following papers were published from the support of this grant:

  2. V. T. Parthasarathy, et al, "Facile Solution Processed MoS2-PEDOT:PSS Mixed Structure as Flexible Paper-Based Infra-Red Sensor", Science Advances Today, 3, 25268, 2017 
  3. S. Deng, et al, "Confined, Oriented and Electrically Anisotropic Graphene Wrinkles on Bacteria", ACS Nano, 10 (9), 8403, 2016
  4. S. Deng and V. Berry*, "Wrinkled, Rippled and Crumpled Graphene: An Overview of Formation Mechanism, Electronic Properties, and Applications", Materials Today, 19 (14), 197-212, 2016
  5. R. Debbarma, et al, “Electrical Transport and Network Percolation in Graphene and Boron Nitride Mixed-Platelet Structures”, ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces, 8 (13), 8721-27, 2016
  6. S. Behura, et al, "Large-Area, Transfer-Free, Oxide-Assisted, Synthesis of Hexagonal Boron Nitride Films and their Heterostructures with MoS2 and WS2", Journal of American Chemical Society, 137 (40), 13060-13065, 2015
  7. S. Behura and V. Berry*, "Interfacial Non-Degenerate Doping of MoS2 and other 2D Semiconductors", ACS Nano, 9 (3), 2227-2230, 2015
  8. T. S. Sreeprasad, et al, "Graphene Cytobot: Single Spore Hydraulics for Electron-Tunneling Modulation between Quantum Dots for Biomechanical Applications", Scientific Reports, 5, 9138, 2015
  9. P. Nguyen, et al, “MoS2 quantum dots interfaced with hydroscopic polyelectrolyte for water gated devices”, Science Letters, 4, 118, 2015
  10. D. Briggs, et al, “Wrinkling Graphene with Bacteria and Functionalization of MoS2 for Electronic Applications”, ECS Transactions, 64 (6), 479-489, 2014
  11. T. S. Sreeprasad, et al, “Electron-Tunneling Modulation in Percolating-Network of Graphene Quantum Dots: Fabrication, Phenomenological Understanding, and Humidity/Pressure Sensing Applications”, Nano Letters, 13 (4), 1757–1763, 2013
  12. V. Berry*, “Impermeability of Graphene and its Applications”, Carbon, 62, 1–10, 2013
  13. P. Nguyen, et al, " Covalent Functionalization of Dipole-Modulating Molecules on Trilayer Graphene: An Avenue for Graphene-Interfaced Molecular Machines", Small, 9, 3823-3828, 2013
  14. T. S. Sreeprasad and V. Berry*, “How do the Electrical Properties of Graphene change with its Functionalization?”, Small, 9, 341-350, 2013

Broader Impacts: The electrical properties of GQDs and the nanotomy process developed as a part of this work have been adopted by several research groups around the world. This project was conducted partly in Kansas State University and partly at University of Illinois at Chicago. At Kansas State University, several concepts from the field of nanoprocessing were incorporated into courses on Materials Science for Chemical Engineers and Chemical Reactions Engineering. The PI also organized three sessions for the Engineering Summer School Institute (ESSI) at KSU, where 10th and 11th grade students were familiarized with nanotechnology concepts and encouraged to consider a career in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). The PI also organized three tracks for the Exploring Science, Technology, and Engineering (EXCITE) programs, where ~30 high-school female students used GQDs to build and test a humidity sensor, which eventially led to a paper: Nano Letters, 13 (4), 1757–1763, 2013. At UIC, the PI organized a summer workshop for high-school female students on fabrication and testing of solar-cells to encouraged them to consider further education in STEM.

As a part of the proposal, the PI has trained 4 different PhD students (3 have graduated: two research scientists (Ocular VR and Air-Liquide) and one post-doctoral fellow (Northwestern)) and 12 undergraduate students. These students have received thorough training in nanotomy, nanomaterial processing, structural characterization, electrical characterization, spectroscopy, device fabrication, and chemical functionalization. Apart from the research publications, the research results were presented at several conferences and universities. On educational front, the PI incorporated nanotechnology concepts into chemical engineering curricula at UIC and KSU, and brought students from classroom to laboratory space.
